rice.awd.pests 0.0.0.9000

    • Sheath Blight Analysis

Sheath Blight Analysis

Adam H Sparks

2018-05-08

Source: vignettes/Third_data_analysis.Rmd
Third_data_analysis.Rmd

Based on the residual plots where several do not meet assumptions for a normal distribution, I’ve elected to use MCMCglmm() for a split plot analysis rather than a lmer() model. The MCMCglmm() model will work for all the data regardless of the residuals.

Interpreting These Analyses

The MCMCglmm documentation provides an excellent resource for interpreting the outputs for each of the models below.

library(MCMCglmm)
vignette("Overview")
vignette("CourseNotes")

When comparing the treatments in the analysis, the model compares each treatment to the base (control) treatment.

The base levels for this analysis are:

  • 2015

    • NRTE:0

    • WMGT:FLD

  • 2016

    • NRTE:60

    • WMGT:FLD

Changes between 2015 and 2016

Before the analysis, note that due to changes between the years, the analysis must be carried out on each year separately. The 2015 data and 2016 data cannot be combined due to changes in inoculation methods; there are other changes too, but the main one is this. Therefore, the analyses will be conducted separately such that comparisons will only be observational and cannot be statistically compared.

MCMCglmm Model Fitting Notes

Fitting the models with the default iterations resulted in some less than acceptable models. Because of this, the number of iterations has been increased, nitt = 55000, and burnin = 5000 and thin = 10. This results in a sample size of 5000 and much smaller errors for random effects and better models.

Setup

Use set.seed() for reproducibility.

library(coda)
library(dplyr)
library(rice.awd.pests)
library(reshape2)
library(magrittr)
library(MCMCglmm)
library(parallel)
library(plotMCMC)
library(tidyr)

set.seed(27)

The AUDPS object is loaded with the rice.awd.pests R package. To see how the AUDPC data were generated from the original raw data, see the https://github.com/openplantpathology/rice_awd_pests/blob/master/data-raw file. However, because it is a tibble() and the treatments exist in a single column for graphing the raw data, this object needs a few minor changes to be usable for the analysis.

Create individual data frames for the analysis.

# create 2015 data frame
AUDPS_2015 <- as.data.frame(AUDPS[AUDPS$YEAR == 2015, ])
AUDPS_2015 <- droplevels(AUDPS_2015)

# relevel factors for easier interpretation of  analysis
AUDPS_2015 <- within(AUDPS_2015, NRTE <- relevel(NRTE, ref = "N0"))
AUDPS_2015 <- within(AUDPS_2015, WMGT <- relevel(WMGT, ref = "FLD"))

# create 2016 data frame
AUDPS_2016 <- as.data.frame(AUDPS[AUDPS$YEAR == 2016, ])
AUDPS_2016 <- droplevels(AUDPS_2016)

# relevel factors for easier interpretation of  analysis
AUDPS_2016 <- within(AUDPS_2016, NRTE <- relevel(NRTE, ref = "N60"))
AUDPS_2016 <- within(AUDPS_2016, WMGT <- relevel(WMGT, ref = "FLD"))

Now that the AUDPS_2015 and AUDPS_2016 data.frames() exist, we can start the analysis.

Specify Priors

As MCMCglmm is a Bayesian analysis, it requires priors to be set. Here we set flat noninformative priors that have a uniform low degree of belief in all parameters for all four of the models we will create.

prior <- list(R = list(V = diag(2), nu = 1.02),
              G = list(G1 = list(V = diag(2), nu = 1.02),
                       G2 = list(V = diag(2), nu = 1.02))
              )

A Note About the Models

The models are all multivariate models. This makes the models more complex, but reduces the number of models from six to four and accounts for correlation between the tiller sheath blight incidence and severity on the tiller and severity on leaves.

2015 Models

2015 Tiller Sheath Blight Severity Model

m1 <- mclapply(1:4, function(i) {
  MCMCglmm(
    fixed = cbind(TShB_inc_AUDPS, TShB_percent_AUDPS) ~
    trait + trait:WMGT * trait:NRTE - 1,
    random = ~ us(trait):REP + us(trait):WMGT:REP,
    rcov = ~ us(trait):units,
    data = AUDPS_2015,
    verbose = FALSE,
    prior = prior,
    family = c("gaussian", "gaussian"),
    nitt = 55000,
    burnin = 5000,
    thin = 10)
}, mc.cores = 4)


m1 <- lapply(m1, function(m) m$Sol)
m1 <- do.call(mcmc.list, m1)

summary(m1)

2015 Leaf Sheath Blight Severity Model

m2 <- mclapply(1:4, function(i) {
  MCMCglmm(
    fixed = cbind(TShB_inc_AUDPS, LShB_percent_AUDPS) ~
      trait + trait:WMGT * trait:NRTE - 1,
    random = ~ us(trait):REP + us(trait):WMGT:REP,
    rcov = ~ us(trait):units,
    data = AUDPS_2015,
    verbose = FALSE,
    prior = prior,
    family = c("gaussian", "gaussian"),
    nitt = 55000,
    burnin = 5000,
    thin = 10)
}, mc.cores = 4)

m2 <- lapply(m2, function(m) m$Sol)
m2 <- do.call(mcmc.list, m2)

2016 Models

2016 Tiller Sheath Blight Severity Model

m3 <- mclapply(1:4, function(i) {
  MCMCglmm(
    fixed = cbind(TShB_inc_AUDPS, TShB_percent_AUDPS) ~
      trait + trait:WMGT * trait:NRTE - 1,
    random = ~ us(trait):REP + us(trait):WMGT:REP,
    rcov = ~ us(trait):units,
    data = AUDPS_2016,
    verbose = FALSE,
    prior = prior,
    family = c("gaussian", "gaussian"),
    nitt = 55000,
    burnin = 5000,
    thin = 10)
}, mc.cores = 4)


m3 <- lapply(m3, function(m) m$Sol)
m3 <- do.call(mcmc.list, m3)

par(mfrow = c(12, 2), mar = c(2, 1, 1, 1))
plot(m4, ask = FALSE, auto.layout = FALSE)

plot_estimates(m4)

Model Fit and Convergence

The models all appear to be good fits.

None of the diagnostic plots show any signs of auto-correlation or any other obvious patterns that would indicate issues with the models.

The Gelman diagnostics indicate that all of the models successfully converged.

Conclusions

Tiller Sheath Blight Incidence

In 2015 the nitrogen rate N120 was significant when compared with the base N0 rate but N100 was not. The irrigation management was not significantly different nor were the interactions of N rate and irrigation.

In 2016 the nitrogen rate N180, was significantly different than the base N60 rate, irrigation management was not significantly different and neither was the interaction of N rate and irrigation management.

Tiller Sheath Blight Severity

In 2015 both the N100 and N120 rates were significantly different than the N0 treatment. The AWD irrigation management was not significantly different from the base FLD treatment and neither interaction appeard to be significant.

In 2016 the N180 was significantly different from the N60 rate. The AWD irrigation management was not significantly different from the base FLD treatment, nor was the interaction of irrigation and N rate.

Leaf Sheath Blight Severity

In 2015 both the N100 and N120 rates were significantly different than the N0 treatment. The AWD irrigation management was not significantly different from the control FLD treatment. However, the interaction of N100 and irrigation was significant while the interaction of N120 and irrigation was not.

In 2016 irrigation management was not significantly different from the base treatments for leaf sheath blight severity. However, the N180 and interaction of N treatment and irrigation were significantly different than the base.

Save Model Information

This step saves the model information used in the posterior estimate graphs to be used in the paper.

models <- list("TInc_15" = m1,
               "TSev_15" = m2,
               "LSev_15" = m3,
               "TInc_16" = m4)
saveRDS(models, "../analysis/data/derived_data/models.Rds")
